Demand for each good and services can be obtained by individual consumerâ€™s 
preference and their budgets.
Demand represent the amount of wiliness to pay of the society. 
1. Demand curve
The total number of units purchased at that price is called the quantity 
demanded. 
So, In economic terminology, demand is not the same as quantity demanded. 
Demand is mean the relationship between a range of prices and the quantities 
demanded at those prices.
1. Demand curve
P         Q
P         Q 
Economists call this inverse relationship between price and quantity 
demanded the law of demand. 
The law of demand assumes that all other variables that affect demand are 
held constant.
1. Demand curve
Q
P
1. Demand curve
Demand curves can somewhat different for each product. 
They may appear relatively steep or flat, or they may be straight or curved. 
Nearly all demand curves share the fundamental similarity that they slope 
down from left to right. 
2. Supply curve
Quantity supplied means the amount of some good or service a producer is 
willing to supply at each price. 
Price is what the producer receives for selling one unit of a good or service. 
A rise in price almost always leads to an increase in the quantity supplied of 
that good or service, while a fall in price will decrease the quantity supplied.
2. Supply curve
Q
P
3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess supply
Q
P
Demand
Supply
E
800
18000
1200
3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess supply
What will be happened in next?
Some chicken houses can not sell their chickens. So, Raw chickens, oils, flours 
at their storages starts to go bad.
Some chicken houses will want to cut prices, because it is better to sell at a 
lower price than not to sell at all. 
So, if the price is above the equilibrium level, incentives built into the structure 
of demand and supply pressures for the price to fall toward the equilibrium.
3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess demand
Q
P
Demand
Supply
E
800
12000
1200
3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess demand
Consumers always are waiting their order and chicken houses says that they 
are filled with orders and there are no more stock of raw meats.
Itâ€™s not difficult for chicken houses to realize that even if they raise the price, 
they can sell their stock out.
So, if the price is below the equilibrium level, incentives built into the structure 
of demand and supply pressures for the price to rise toward the equilibrium.
4. Equilibrium
Q
P
Demand
Supply
Q* = 1000
P*
=15000
E
Eâ€™
4. Equilibrium
The word â€œequilibriumâ€ means â€œbalance.â€ 
If a market is at its equilibrium price and quantity, then it has no reason to 
move away from that point. 
However, if a market is not at equilibrium, then economic pressures arise to 
move the market toward the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity.
4. Equilibrium
In 1890, the famous economist Alfred Marshall wrote that asking whether 
supply or demand determined a price was like arguing
â€œwhether it is the upper or the 
under blade of a pair of 
scissors that cuts a piece of 
paper.â€ 

5. Shift of demand curve
Price, however, is not the only thing that influences demand and supply.
What if overall consumerâ€™s income has changed? 
Sometime preferences can be suddenly changed.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
5. Shift of demand curve
Q
P
D0
1000
E
15000
800
18000
1200
D1
D2
5. Shift of demand curve
Does the higher income always bring greater demand?
A product whose demand rises when income rises is called a normal good.
but, there is a few exceptions to this pattern do exist. 
A product whose demand falls when income rises is called an inferior good. 
5. Shift of demand curve
And, for some goods such as luxury cars, fine cuisines, or jewelry, the effect of 
a rise in income can be especially pronounced.
We called those luxury goods.
A luxury good is a good for which demand increases more than proportionally 
as income rises, 
5. Shift of demand curve
Of course, income is not the only factor that causes a shift in demand.
We can think about some of other factors that shift demand curves.
One of those is changing tastes or preferences.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
It might cause a severe avoiding to eat chickens.
5. Shift of demand curve
Demographic changes can also be a important factor.
Actually, the demographic changes is combined with the changes in preference.
Since the consumption preference of youth and old person is quite different, 
changes in the demographic structure directly affects the overall preference of 
the society.
5. Shift of demand curve
Another example is the housing demand.
Since the demand for owning houses is usually peaked in the middle age about 
40s, the overall housing demand can also be peaked, when the number of 
middle-aged in the country is the highest level.
Some economists have tried to predict the future housing prices by using 
predictable demographic changes.
Mankiw, N. G., & Weil, D. N. (1989). The baby boom, the baby bust, and the 
housing market. Regional science and urban economics, 19(2), 235-258.
5. Shift of demand curve
It is also true that expectations about the future price (or expectations about 
tastes and preferences, income, and so on) can affect demand.
For example, if people hear that a hurricane is coming, they may rush to the 
store to buy flashlight batteries and bottled water. 
These changes can push the demand curve to the right.
5. Shift of demand curve
One interest thing is that some goods can be seriously affected by the 
expectation.
For example, we can think about housing market.
Demand for housing is not only determined  by preferences, but also by the 
expectations for capital gain.
This feature of housing markets sometimes causes speculations in housing 
markets.
6. Shift of supply curve
How about the supply curves? 
One of most important factor affecting the supply curve might be the 
production cost.
If a firm faces lower costs of production, a firmâ€™s profits go up. This can be 
shown by the supply curve shifting to the right.
if a firm faces higher costs of production, then it will earn lower profits at any 
given selling price for its products. In this case, the supply curve shifts to the 
left.
6. Shift of supply curve
Q
P
S0
1000
E
15000
800
18000
1200
S1 S2
6. Shift of supply curve
Several other things affect the cost of production, too. 
We can think about new technologies for production, and some government 
policies.
6. Shift of supply curve
When producers develops or discovers a technology that allows the firm to 
produce at a lower cost, the supply curve will shift to the right, as well. 
Think about the cost of raising a chicken in chicken farm and the poultry 
factory system.

6. Shift of supply curve
Government policies also can affect the cost of production and the supply 
curve through taxes, regulations, and subsidies.
A subsidy occurs when the government pays a firm directly or reduces the 
firmâ€™s taxes if the firm carries out certain actions. 
From the firmâ€™s perspective, taxes or regulations are an additional cost of 
production that shifts supply to the left, leading the firm to produce a lower 
quantity at every given price. 
So, government subsidies reduce the cost of production and increase supply at 
every given price, shifting supply to the right.
7. Price controls
In some cases, discontent over prices turns into public pressure on politicians

7. Price controls
Laws that government enacts to regulate prices are called Price controls.
Price controls come in two ways.
A price ceiling keeps a price from rising above a certain level.
And, a price floor keeps a price from falling below a certain level. 
7. Price controls

P

18000

7. Price controls
A price floor is the lowest legal price that can be paid in the market.
Price floors are sometimes called price supports. 
Because they support a price by preventing it from falling below a certain level. 
7. Price controls
Q
P
1000
15000
Eâ€™

E
7. Price controls
The demand and supply model shows how people and firms will react to the 
incentives provided by these laws to control prices.
As a result, It will often lead to undesirable consequences. 
It implies alternative policy tools can often achieve the desired goals of price 
control laws, while avoiding at least some of their costs and tradeoffs.

1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ Suppose there is a consumer whose name is Pepe. He is the representative agent of all customers in our 
society.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ We want to capture that consumers have a limited amount of income to spend on the things they need and 
want.
â€¢ Pepe has 5,600 wons in spending money each week.
â€¢ He can allocate this spending between meal ticket and shirts. 
â€¢ The meal tickets cost 700 wons each, and the shirts are 1,400 wons each.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ Of course, the budget constraint diagram containing just two goods is not realistic. 
â€¢ Because, in a modern economy, people choose from thousands of goods.
â€¢ However, thinking about a model with many goods can be just a straightforward extension of what we 
discussed here.
â€¢ The point is that there is always a trade-off problem in decisions.

1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ Economists call it opportunity cost.
â€¢ Opportunity cost indicate what have to be given up to obtain something. In other words, opportunity cost 
is the value of the next best alternative.
â€¢ For Pepe, the opportunity cost of 1 shirt is the 2 meal tickets. 
â€¢ He would decide to buy one more shirt, If the value of the extra shirt exceed the value of the alternative 
(2 meal tickets).
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ A fundamental principle of economics is that every choice has an opportunity cost.
â€¢ If you sleep through your economics class, the opportunity cost might be the time which would be spent 
to make up the class.
â€¢ If you choose to marry one person, you give up the opportunity to marry anyone else. 
â€¢ In short, opportunity cost is all around us and part of human existence.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ In many cases, it is reasonable to refer to the opportunity cost as the price.
â€¢ For example, attending graduate school is the case where the opportunity cost exceeds the monetary cost. 
The explicit costs of attending college might be about tuition, books, room and board, and other expenses. 
But in addition, during the hours that you are attending class and studying, it is impossible to work at a 
paying job. Thus, graduate school imposes both an out-of-pocket cost and an opportunity cost of lost 
earnings.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ What if the price of a good changes?
â€¢ Suppose that, the price of bus ticket increased to 1,400 won.
â€¢ A price increase for bus tickets would have no effect on the ability to purchase Ramen. 
â€¢ But it would reduce the number of bus tickets which Pepe could afford to buy.

2. Utility
â€¢ People desire goods and services for the satisfaction or utility from using those goods and services.
â€¢ Utility is the term which economists use to describe a personâ€™s level of satisfaction/usefulness or 
happiness with his or her choices.
â€¢ Of course, in our daily life, we donâ€™t measure such a thing. But, in model, it can be a quite useful 
instrument to replicate the underlying incentive structure of each individuals.
2. Utility
Economists assume the feature of utility
1.The more of some good one consumes, the more utility 
one obtains.
2. As a person consumes more of a good, the additional (or 
marginal) utility from each additional unit of the good 
declines.
2. Utility
â€¢ It is a general pattern that consumption of the first few units of good tends to bring a higher level of 
utility than consumption of later units.
â€¢ Suppose that you are in thirsty. You can compare the degree to which the first few drops of water relieve 
the thirst and the extent to which the drinking water later resolves the thirst.
â€¢ Economists refer to this pattern as the law of diminishing marginal utility.
â€¢ It means that, the utility of a person receives from consuming the first unit of a good is typically more 
than the utility received from consuming the fifth or the tenth unit of that same good.
2. Utility
â€¢ The law of diminishing marginal utility explains why people and societies rarely make all-or-nothing 
choices. 
â€¢ Most of people would not say, â€œMy favorite food is potato, so I will eat nothing but only potatoes from 
now on.â€
â€¢ Even if you get a very high level of utility from your favorite food, if you ate it exclusively, the marginal 
utility from those last few servings would not be very high. 
2. Utility

â€¢ When a price changes,

Price effect
â€¢ Price effect : an increase in price causes an decrease in demand (-)
* Special case : Giffen goods â€“ price effect (+)
â€¢ Relationship between goods
â€¢ Substitute goods : an increase in the demand of A causes an decrease in the demand of B (-)
â€¢ Complementary goods : an increase in the demand of A causes an increase in the demand of B (+)
â€¢ Then, consider price effect on other good
â€¢ On substitute goods : an increase in the price of A causes an increase in the demand of B (+)
â€¢ On complementary goods : an increase in the price of A causes an decrease in the demand of B (-)

**Keywords**
â€¢ What is the producerâ€™s optimal decision?
â€¢ Production cost
â€¢ Fixed cost and variable cost
â€¢ Average cost and marginal cost
â€¢ Production function
â¢ The law of diminishing marginal production
â€¢ Total revenue, average revenue, and marginal revenue
Producerâ€™s optimization problem
â—¦ Business sector or firms combines inputs of labor, capital, land, and raw or 
finished component materials to produce outputs.
â—¦ This activity of production includes not only manufacturing but also any 
process or service that creates value, including transportation, distribution, 
wholesale and retail sales.
â—¦ The objective of business : profit
Producerâ€™s optimization problem
â—¦ Profit = Revenue â€“ cost
â—¦ Revenue = Price Ã— Quantity
â—¦ Cost = the amount that the firm pays to make and sell their products is called total cost. 
â—¦ The cost structure of firms can be broken down into some 
common underlying patterns. In the short run, we can classify the 
costs into fixed costs and variable costs.
â—¦ Fixed costs are the costs that cannot be changed in the short run.
â—¦ Variable costs are the costs that can be changed.
The structure of production cost
â—¦ Fixed costs are expenditures that do not change regardless of the level of 
production, at least not in the short term.
â—¦ For example, the cost of building factory or buying heavy equipment, research and 
development costs, advertising expenses. 
â—¦ The level of fixed costs varies according to the feature of the products or 
industry. 
â—¦ For instance, manufacturing mobile phone or computer chips requires an 
expensive factory. But, a food-truck or a painting artist can get by with 
relatively less fixed costs.
The structure of production cost
â—¦ Variable costs are incurred in the act of producing.
â—¦ For example, wages and cost to buy intermediate goods are variable costs.
â—¦ The more you produce, the greater the variable cost.
â—¦ Total cost = fixed cost + variable cost.
The nature of production
â—¦ Two assumptions:
1. Positivity (with respect to input)
2. Law of diminishing marginal production
â—¦ Marginal product of any input : the additional quantity of output obtained 
from one additional unit of that input.
Example : Pepeâ€™s chicken house
â—¦ Assume that the fixed costs of operating the chicken house, including the space and 
equipment, are 100.
â—¦ The variable costs are the costs of hiring worker, which in our example is 50 per deliver. 
â—¦ Variable cost :  price of input  x  quantity of input.
â—¦ When one unit of the input (worker) is added, the cost would be increased as much as the 
price of the input (50 for the wage).

such as 11 seconds, average record with the additional record

holistic_chapters.chapter_full_text:
Introduction 
of economics
: Market Equilibrium
HANDONG GLOBAL UNIVERSITY
0. Introduction
In this week, we will learn about:
- Demand, Supply, and Equilibrium in Markets for 
Goods and Services
-   Shifts in Demand and Supply curves
- Changes in Equilibrium Price and Quantity
- Price Ceilings and Price Floors
Market Equilibrium
Firm
1
Firm
2
Firm
3
Firm
4
Firm
5
Good & 
service 
market
Production 
factor 
market
1. Demand curve
Demand the amount of some good or service consumers are willing and able 
to purchase at each price. 
Demand for each good and services can be obtained by individual consumerâ€™s 
preference and their budgets.
Demand represent the amount of wiliness to pay of the society. 
1. Demand curve
The total number of units purchased at that price is called the quantity 
demanded. 
So, In economic terminology, demand is not the same as quantity demanded. 
Demand is mean the relationship between a range of prices and the quantities 
demanded at those prices.
1. Demand curve
P         Q
P         Q 
Economists call this inverse relationship between price and quantity 
demanded the law of demand. 
The law of demand assumes that all other variables that affect demand are 
held constant.
1. Demand curve
Q
P
1. Demand curve
Demand curves can somewhat different for each product. 
They may appear relatively steep or flat, or they may be straight or curved. 
Nearly all demand curves share the fundamental similarity that they slope 
down from left to right. 
2. Supply curve
Quantity supplied means the amount of some good or service a producer is 
willing to supply at each price. 
Price is what the producer receives for selling one unit of a good or service. 
A rise in price almost always leads to an increase in the quantity supplied of 
that good or service, while a fall in price will decrease the quantity supplied.
2. Supply curve
Q
P
3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess supply
Q
P
Demand
Supply
E
800
18000
1200
3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess supply
What will be happened in next?
Some chicken houses can not sell their chickens. So, Raw chickens, oils, flours 
at their storages starts to go bad.
Some chicken houses will want to cut prices, because it is better to sell at a 
lower price than not to sell at all. 
So, if the price is above the equilibrium level, incentives built into the structure 
of demand and supply pressures for the price to fall toward the equilibrium.
3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess demand
Q
P
Demand
Supply
E
800
12000
1200
3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess demand
Consumers always are waiting their order and chicken houses says that they 
are filled with orders and there are no more stock of raw meats.
Itâ€™s not difficult for chicken houses to realize that even if they raise the price, 
they can sell their stock out.
So, if the price is below the equilibrium level, incentives built into the structure 
of demand and supply pressures for the price to rise toward the equilibrium.
4. Equilibrium
Q
P
Demand
Supply
Q* = 1000
P*
=15000
E
Eâ€™
4. Equilibrium
The word â€œequilibriumâ€ means â€œbalance.â€ 
If a market is at its equilibrium price and quantity, then it has no reason to 
move away from that point. 
However, if a market is not at equilibrium, then economic pressures arise to 
move the market toward the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity.
4. Equilibrium
In 1890, the famous economist Alfred Marshall wrote that asking whether 
supply or demand determined a price was like arguing
â€œwhether it is the upper or the 
under blade of a pair of 
scissors that cuts a piece of 
paper.â€ 
5. Shift of demand curve
Price, however, is not the only thing that influences demand and supply.
What if overall consumerâ€™s income has changed? 
Sometime preferences can be suddenly changed.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
5. Shift of demand curve
Q
P
D0
1000
E
15000
800
18000
1200
D1
D2
5. Shift of demand curve
Does the higher income always bring greater demand?
A product whose demand rises when income rises is called a normal good.
but, there is a few exceptions to this pattern do exist. 
A product whose demand falls when income rises is called an inferior good. 
5. Shift of demand curve
And, for some goods such as luxury cars, fine cuisines, or jewelry, the effect of 
a rise in income can be especially pronounced.
We called those luxury goods.
A luxury good is a good for which demand increases more than proportionally 
as income rises, 
5. Shift of demand curve
Of course, income is not the only factor that causes a shift in demand.
We can think about some of other factors that shift demand curves.
One of those is changing tastes or preferences.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
It might cause a severe avoiding to eat chickens.
5. Shift of demand curve
Demographic changes can also be a important factor.
Actually, the demographic changes is combined with the changes in preference.
Since the consumption preference of youth and old person is quite different, 
changes in the demographic structure directly affects the overall preference of 
the society.
5. Shift of demand curve
Another example is the housing demand.
Since the demand for owning houses is usually peaked in the middle age about 
40s, the overall housing demand can also be peaked, when the number of 
middle-aged in the country is the highest level.
Some economists have tried to predict the future housing prices by using 
predictable demographic changes.
Mankiw, N. G., & Weil, D. N. (1989). The baby boom, the baby bust, and the 
housing market. Regional science and urban economics, 19(2), 235-258.
5. Shift of demand curve
It is also true that expectations about the future price (or expectations about 
tastes and preferences, income, and so on) can affect demand.
For example, if people hear that a hurricane is coming, they may rush to the 
store to buy flashlight batteries and bottled water. 
These changes can push the demand curve to the right.
5. Shift of demand curve
One interest thing is that some goods can be seriously affected by the 
expectation.
For example, we can think about housing market.
Demand for housing is not only determined  by preferences, but also by the 
expectations for capital gain.
This feature of housing markets sometimes causes speculations in housing 
markets.
6. Shift of supply curve
How about the supply curves? 
One of most important factor affecting the supply curve might be the 
production cost.
If a firm faces lower costs of production, a firmâ€™s profits go up. This can be 
shown by the supply curve shifting to the right.
if a firm faces higher costs of production, then it will earn lower profits at any 
given selling price for its products. In this case, the supply curve shifts to the 
left.
6. Shift of supply curve
Q
P
S0
1000
E
15000
800
18000
1200
S1 S2
6. Shift of supply curve
Several other things affect the cost of production, too. 
We can think about new technologies for production, and some government 
policies.
6. Shift of supply curve
When producers develops or discovers a technology that allows the firm to 
produce at a lower cost, the supply curve will shift to the right, as well. 
Think about the cost of raising a chicken in chicken farm and the poultry 
factory system.
6. Shift of supply curve
Government policies also can affect the cost of production and the supply 
curve through taxes, regulations, and subsidies.
A subsidy occurs when the government pays a firm directly or reduces the 
firmâ€™s taxes if the firm carries out certain actions. 
From the firmâ€™s perspective, taxes or regulations are an additional cost of 
production that shifts supply to the left, leading the firm to produce a lower 
quantity at every given price. 
So, government subsidies reduce the cost of production and increase supply at 
every given price, shifting supply to the right.
7. Price controls
In some cases, discontent over prices turns into public pressure on politicians
7. Price controls
Laws that government enacts to regulate prices are called Price controls.
Price controls come in two ways.
A price ceiling keeps a price from rising above a certain level.
And, a price floor keeps a price from falling below a certain level. 
7. Price controls
Q
P
1000
18000
15000 E0
E1
1200
7. Price controls
Q
P
1000
15000
E2
1500
7. Price controls
A price floor is the lowest legal price that can be paid in the market.
Price floors are sometimes called price supports. 
Because they support a price by preventing it from falling below a certain level. 
7. Price controls
Q
P
1000
15000
Eâ€™
1500
E
7. Price controls
The demand and supply model shows how people and firms will react to the 
incentives provided by these laws to control prices.
As a result, It will often lead to undesirable consequences. 
It implies alternative policy tools can often achieve the desired goals of price 
control laws, while avoiding at least some of their costs and tradeoffs.

â€¢ Experiencing an economic modelling
â€¢ Understanding the concept of budgets constraint and opportunity cost
â€¢ Understanding the concepts of utility and marginal utility
â€¢ Solving the consumerâ€™s optimization problem with the marginal analysis
â€¢ Learning the feature of optimal consumption decisions
â€¢ Deriving a demand curve
Goals
Introduction
1.  Model description 
â€¢  What they can choose? Budget constraint
â€¢  What is their objective? Utility function
â€¢  How do they behave? Maximization of the objective under the constraint (rationality)
2. Maximization of the utility subject to the budget constraint
â€¢  Marginal analysis
3.  Derivation of a demand curve
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ Suppose there is a consumer whose name is Pepe. He is the representative agent of all customers in our 
society.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ We want to capture that consumers have a limited amount of income to spend on the things they need and 
want.
â€¢ Pepe has 5,600 wons in spending money each week.
â€¢ He can allocate this spending between meal ticket and shirts. 
â€¢ The meal tickets cost 700 wons each, and the shirts are 1,400 wons each.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ Of course, the budget constraint diagram containing just two goods is not realistic. 
â€¢ Because, in a modern economy, people choose from thousands of goods.
â€¢ However, thinking about a model with many goods can be just a straightforward extension of what we 
discussed here.
â€¢ The point is that there is always a trade-off problem in decisions.
1. Budget Constraint

1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ The slope of the budget constraint is 
determined by the relative price. 
â€¢ Relative price - How many meal 
tickets would Pepe have to give up to 
get one more shirt, while staying 
within his budget?
â€¢ All along the budget set, getting 1 
shirt means giving up 2 meal tickets.
Meal tickets

1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ Economists call it opportunity cost.
â€¢ Opportunity cost indicate what have to be given up to obtain something. In other words, opportunity cost 
is the value of the next best alternative.
â€¢ For Pepe, the opportunity cost of 1 shirt is the 2 meal tickets. 
â€¢ He would decide to buy one more shirt, If the value of the extra shirt exceed the value of the alternative 
(2 meal tickets).
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ A fundamental principle of economics is that every choice has an opportunity cost.
â€¢ If you sleep through your economics class, the opportunity cost might be the time which would be spent 
to make up the class.
â€¢ If you choose to marry one person, you give up the opportunity to marry anyone else. 
â€¢ In short, opportunity cost is all around us and part of human existence.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ In many cases, it is reasonable to refer to the opportunity cost as the price.
â€¢ For example, attending graduate school is the case where the opportunity cost exceeds the monetary cost. 
The explicit costs of attending college might be about tuition, books, room and board, and other expenses. 
But in addition, during the hours that you are attending class and studying, it is impossible to work at a 
paying job. Thus, graduate school imposes both an out-of-pocket cost and an opportunity cost of lost 
earnings.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ What if the price of a good changes?
â€¢ Suppose that, the price of bus ticket increased to 1,400 won.
â€¢ A price increase for bus tickets would have no effect on the ability to purchase Ramen. 
â€¢ But it would reduce the number of bus tickets which Pepe could afford to buy.
â€¢ What happens in the budget constraint? Redraw it. 
1. Budget Constraint

â€¢ Suppose that, his income drops as a half(=2,800 won).
â€¢ In this case, it would reduce the number of both of meal tickets and shirts which Pepe could afford to buy.

2. Utility
â€¢ People desire goods and services for the satisfaction or utility from using those goods and services.
â€¢ Utility is the term which economists use to describe a personâ€™s level of satisfaction/usefulness or 
happiness with his or her choices.
â€¢ Of course, in our daily life, we donâ€™t measure such a thing. But, in model, it can be a quite useful 
instrument to replicate the underlying incentive structure of each individuals.
2. Utility
Economists assume the feature of utility
1.The more of some good one consumes, the more utility 
one obtains.
2. As a person consumes more of a good, the additional (or 
marginal) utility from each additional unit of the good 
declines.
2. Utility
â€¢ It is a general pattern that consumption of the first few units of good tends to bring a higher level of 
utility than consumption of later units.
â€¢ Suppose that you are in thirsty. You can compare the degree to which the first few drops of water relieve 
the thirst and the extent to which the drinking water later resolves the thirst.
â€¢ Economists refer to this pattern as the law of diminishing marginal utility.
â€¢ It means that, the utility of a person receives from consuming the first unit of a good is typically more 
than the utility received from consuming the fifth or the tenth unit of that same good.
2. Utility
â€¢ The law of diminishing marginal utility explains why people and societies rarely make all-or-nothing 
choices. 
â€¢ Most of people would not say, â€œMy favorite food is potato, so I will eat nothing but only potatoes from 
now on.â€
â€¢ Even if you get a very high level of utility from your favorite food, if you ate it exclusively, the marginal 
utility from those last few servings would not be very high. 
2. Utility
â€¢ An example for the marginal utilities for meal ticket (and shirt):

Marginal analysis
â€¢ The marginal approach is based on looking at the tradeoffs(measured in terms of marginal utility per 
spending) of consuming less of one good and more of another.
â€¢ Marginal utility of X = additional utility from consuming 1 more unit (the smallest unit we can imagine) 
of X
â€¢ Which decision is better? Check the marginal utilities.
â€¢ But we have to consider that the prices are different.
â€¢ Relative price indicates how much unit of Y can be exchanged with 1 more X.
â€¢ Marginal utility per spending of X = marginal utility of X / price of X

Income effect
â€¢ Income effect and the characteristics of good
â€¢ Normal goods : an increase in income causes an increase in demand (+)
â€¢ Inferior goods : an increase in income causes a decrease in demand (-)
â€¢ Luxury goods : an increase in income causes a bigger percentage increase in demand (++)

â€¢ When a price changes,
â€¢ Substitution effect : change in relative price (the slope in budget constraint)
â€¢ Income effect (of a price change) : shift in real purchasing power
Price effect
â€¢ Price effect : an increase in price causes an decrease in demand (-)
* Special case : Giffen goods â€“ price effect (+)
â€¢ Relationship between goods
â€¢ Substitute goods : an increase in the demand of A causes an decrease in the demand of B (-)
â€¢ Complementary goods : an increase in the demand of A causes an increase in the demand of B (+)
â€¢ Then, consider price effect on other good
â€¢ On substitute goods : an increase in the price of A causes an increase in the demand of B (+)
â€¢ On complementary goods : an increase in the price of A causes an decrease in the demand of B (-)
Demand curve
â€¢ What is demand curve? The relationship between price and quantity demanded
â€¢ What is the quantity demanded? We know what occurs if consumers follow their self-interest. => The 
optimal decision of consumption
â€¢ Remind that price effect is negative (-).

Lecture 3
: Producer problem and supply curve
Jengei Hong

**Keywords**
â€¢ What is the producerâ€™s optimal decision?
â€¢ Production cost
â€¢ Fixed cost and variable cost
â€¢ Average cost and marginal cost
â€¢ Production function
â¢ The law of diminishing marginal production
â€¢ Total revenue, average revenue, and marginal revenue
Producerâ€™s optimization problem
â—¦ Business sector or firms combines inputs of labor, capital, land, and raw or 
finished component materials to produce outputs.
â—¦ This activity of production includes not only manufacturing but also any 
process or service that creates value, including transportation, distribution, 
wholesale and retail sales.
â—¦ The objective of business : profit
Producerâ€™s optimization problem
â—¦ Profit = Revenue â€“ cost
â—¦ Revenue = Price Ã— Quantity
â—¦ Cost = the amount that the firm pays to make and sell their products is called total cost. 
â—¦ The cost structure of firms can be broken down into some 
common underlying patterns. In the short run, we can classify the 
costs into fixed costs and variable costs.
â—¦ Fixed costs are the costs that cannot be changed in the short run.
â—¦ Variable costs are the costs that can be changed.
The structure of production cost
â—¦ Fixed costs are expenditures that do not change regardless of the level of 
production, at least not in the short term.
â—¦ For example, the cost of building factory or buying heavy equipment, research and 
development costs, advertising expenses. 
â—¦ The level of fixed costs varies according to the feature of the products or 
industry. 
â—¦ For instance, manufacturing mobile phone or computer chips requires an 
expensive factory. But, a food-truck or a painting artist can get by with 
relatively less fixed costs.
The structure of production cost
â—¦ Variable costs are incurred in the act of producing.
â—¦ For example, wages and cost to buy intermediate goods are variable costs.
â—¦ The more you produce, the greater the variable cost.
â—¦ Total cost = fixed cost + variable cost.
The nature of production
â—¦ Two assumptions:
1. Positivity (with respect to input)
2. Law of diminishing marginal production
â—¦ Marginal product of any input : the additional quantity of output obtained 
from one additional unit of that input.
Example : Pepeâ€™s chicken house
â—¦ Assume that the fixed costs of operating the chicken house, including the space and 
equipment, are 100.
â—¦ The variable costs are the costs of hiring worker, which in our example is 50 per deliver. 
â—¦ Variable cost :  price of input  x  quantity of input.
â—¦ When one unit of the input (worker) is added, the cost would be increased as much as the 
price of the input (50 for the wage).
Example : cost structure of the 
chicken house

Introduction 
of economics
: Market Equilibrium
HANDONG GLOBAL UNIVERSITY
0. Introduction
In this week, we will learn about:
- Demand, Supply, and Equilibrium in Markets for 
Goods and Services
-   Shifts in Demand and Supply curves
- Changes in Equilibrium Price and Quantity
- Price Ceilings and Price Floors
Market Equilibrium
Firm
1
Firm
2
Firm
3
Firm
4
Firm
5
Good & 
service 
market
Production 
factor 
market
1. Demand curve
Demand the amount of some good or service consumers are willing and able 
to purchase at each price. 
Demand for each good and services can be obtained by individual consumerâ€™s 
preference and their budgets.
Demand represent the amount of wiliness to pay of the society. 
1. Demand curve
The total number of units purchased at that price is called the quantity 
demanded. 
So, In economic terminology, demand is not the same as quantity demanded. 
Demand is mean the relationship between a range of prices and the quantities 
demanded at those prices.
1. Demand curve
P         Q
P         Q 
Economists call this inverse relationship between price and quantity 
demanded the law of demand. 
The law of demand assumes that all other variables that affect demand are 
held constant.
1. Demand curve
Q
P
1. Demand curve
Demand curves can somewhat different for each product. 
They may appear relatively steep or flat, or they may be straight or curved. 
Nearly all demand curves share the fundamental similarity that they slope 
down from left to right. 
2. Supply curve
Quantity supplied means the amount of some good or service a producer is 
willing to supply at each price. 
Price is what the producer receives for selling one unit of a good or service. 
A rise in price almost always leads to an increase in the quantity supplied of 
that good or service, while a fall in price will decrease the quantity supplied.
2. Supply curve
Q
P
3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess supply
Q
P
Demand
Supply
E
800
18000
1200
3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess supply
What will be happened in next?
Some chicken houses can not sell their chickens. So, Raw chickens, oils, flours 
at their storages starts to go bad.
Some chicken houses will want to cut prices, because it is better to sell at a 
lower price than not to sell at all. 
So, if the price is above the equilibrium level, incentives built into the structure 
of demand and supply pressures for the price to fall toward the equilibrium.
3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess demand
Q
P
Demand
Supply
E
800
12000
1200
3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess demand
Consumers always are waiting their order and chicken houses says that they 
are filled with orders and there are no more stock of raw meats.
Itâ€™s not difficult for chicken houses to realize that even if they raise the price, 
they can sell their stock out.
So, if the price is below the equilibrium level, incentives built into the structure 
of demand and supply pressures for the price to rise toward the equilibrium.
4. Equilibrium
Q
P
Demand
Supply
Q* = 1000
P*
=15000
E
Eâ€™
4. Equilibrium
The word â€œequilibriumâ€ means â€œbalance.â€ 
If a market is at its equilibrium price and quantity, then it has no reason to 
move away from that point. 
However, if a market is not at equilibrium, then economic pressures arise to 
move the market toward the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity.
4. Equilibrium
In 1890, the famous economist Alfred Marshall wrote that asking whether 
supply or demand determined a price was like arguing
â€œwhether it is the upper or the 
under blade of a pair of 
scissors that cuts a piece of 
paper.â€ 
5. Shift of demand curve
Price, however, is not the only thing that influences demand and supply.
What if overall consumerâ€™s income has changed? 
Sometime preferences can be suddenly changed.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
5. Shift of demand curve
Q
P
D0
1000
E
15000
800
18000
1200
D1
D2
5. Shift of demand curve
Does the higher income always bring greater demand?
A product whose demand rises when income rises is called a normal good.
but, there is a few exceptions to this pattern do exist. 
A product whose demand falls when income rises is called an inferior good. 
5. Shift of demand curve
And, for some goods such as luxury cars, fine cuisines, or jewelry, the effect of 
a rise in income can be especially pronounced.
We called those luxury goods.
A luxury good is a good for which demand increases more than proportionally 
as income rises, 
5. Shift of demand curve
Of course, income is not the only factor that causes a shift in demand.
We can think about some of other factors that shift demand curves.
One of those is changing tastes or preferences.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
It might cause a severe avoiding to eat chickens.
5. Shift of demand curve
Demographic changes can also be a important factor.
Actually, the demographic changes is combined with the changes in preference.
Since the consumption preference of youth and old person is quite different, 
changes in the demographic structure directly affects the overall preference of 
the society.
5. Shift of demand curve
Another example is the housing demand.
Since the demand for owning houses is usually peaked in the middle age about 
40s, the overall housing demand can also be peaked, when the number of 
middle-aged in the country is the highest level.
Some economists have tried to predict the future housing prices by using 
predictable demographic changes.
Mankiw, N. G., & Weil, D. N. (1989). The baby boom, the baby bust, and the 
housing market. Regional science and urban economics, 19(2), 235-258.
5. Shift of demand curve
It is also true that expectations about the future price (or expectations about 
tastes and preferences, income, and so on) can affect demand.
For example, if people hear that a hurricane is coming, they may rush to the 
store to buy flashlight batteries and bottled water. 
These changes can push the demand curve to the right.
5. Shift of demand curve
One interest thing is that some goods can be seriously affected by the 
expectation.
For example, we can think about housing market.
Demand for housing is not only determined  by preferences, but also by the 
expectations for capital gain.
This feature of housing markets sometimes causes speculations in housing 
markets.
6. Shift of supply curve
How about the supply curves? 
One of most important factor affecting the supply curve might be the 
production cost.
If a firm faces lower costs of production, a firmâ€™s profits go up. This can be 
shown by the supply curve shifting to the right.
if a firm faces higher costs of production, then it will earn lower profits at any 
given selling price for its products. In this case, the supply curve shifts to the 
left.
6. Shift of supply curve
Q
P
S0
1000
E
15000
800
18000
1200
S1 S2
6. Shift of supply curve
Several other things affect the cost of production, too. 
We can think about new technologies for production, and some government 
policies.
6. Shift of supply curve
When producers develops or discovers a technology that allows the firm to 
produce at a lower cost, the supply curve will shift to the right, as well. 
Think about the cost of raising a chicken in chicken farm and the poultry 
factory system.
6. Shift of supply curve
Government policies also can affect the cost of production and the supply 
curve through taxes, regulations, and subsidies.
A subsidy occurs when the government pays a firm directly or reduces the 
firmâ€™s taxes if the firm carries out certain actions. 
From the firmâ€™s perspective, taxes or regulations are an additional cost of 
production that shifts supply to the left, leading the firm to produce a lower 
quantity at every given price. 
So, government subsidies reduce the cost of production and increase supply at 
every given price, shifting supply to the right.
7. Price controls
In some cases, discontent over prices turns into public pressure on politicians
7. Price controls
Laws that government enacts to regulate prices are called Price controls.
Price controls come in two ways.
A price ceiling keeps a price from rising above a certain level.
And, a price floor keeps a price from falling below a certain level. 
7. Price controls
Q
P
1000
18000
15000 E0
E1
1200
7. Price controls
Q
P
1000
15000
E2
1500
7. Price controls
A price floor is the lowest legal price that can be paid in the market.
Price floors are sometimes called price supports. 
Because they support a price by preventing it from falling below a certain level. 
7. Price controls
Q
P
1000
15000
Eâ€™
1500
E
7. Price controls
The demand and supply model shows how people and firms will react to the 
incentives provided by these laws to control prices.
As a result, It will often lead to undesirable consequences. 
It implies alternative policy tools can often achieve the desired goals of price 
control laws, while avoiding at least some of their costs and tradeoffs.

Goals
Introduction
1.  Model description 
â€¢  What they can choose? Budget constraint
â€¢  What is their objective? Utility function
â€¢  How do they behave? Maximization of the objective under the constraint (rationality)
2. Maximization of the utility subject to the budget constraint

3.  Derivation of a demand curve
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ Suppose there is a consumer whose name is Pepe. He is the representative agent of all customers in our 
society.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ We want to capture that consumers have a limited amount of income to spend on the things they need and 
want.
â€¢ Pepe has 5,600 wons in spending money each week.
â€¢ He can allocate this spending between meal ticket and shirts. 
â€¢ The meal tickets cost 700 wons each, and the shirts are 1,400 wons each.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ Of course, the budget constraint diagram containing just two goods is not realistic. 
â€¢ Because, in a modern economy, people choose from thousands of goods.
â€¢ However, thinking about a model with many goods can be just a straightforward extension of what we 
discussed here.
â€¢ The point is that there is always a trade-off problem in decisions.
1. Budget Constraint

which the total cost adds

1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ If he spend out his budget, we can 
think his budget constraint is actually 
the outer line of the colored area.
â€¢ If he had unlimited income or goods 
were free, then he could consume 
without limit.  
â€¢ Any point outside the constraint is 
not affordable, because it would cost 
more money than Pepe has in his 
budget.

1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ The slope of the budget constraint is 
determined by the relative price. 
â€¢ Relative price - How many meal 
tickets would Pepe have to give up to 
get one more shirt, while staying 
within his budget?
â€¢ All along the budget set, getting 1 
shirt means giving up 2 meal tickets.
Meal tickets

1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ Economists call it opportunity cost.
â€¢ Opportunity cost indicate what have to be given up to obtain something. In other words, opportunity cost 
is the value of the next best alternative.
â€¢ For Pepe, the opportunity cost of 1 shirt is the 2 meal tickets. 
â€¢ He would decide to buy one more shirt, If the value of the extra shirt exceed the value of the alternative 
(2 meal tickets).
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ A fundamental principle of economics is that every choice has an opportunity cost.
â€¢ If you sleep through your economics class, the opportunity cost might be the time which would be spent 
to make up the class.
â€¢ If you choose to marry one person, you give up the opportunity to marry anyone else. 
â€¢ In short, opportunity cost is all around us and part of human existence.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ In many cases, it is reasonable to refer to the opportunity cost as the price.
â€¢ For example, attending graduate school is the case where the opportunity cost exceeds the monetary cost. 
The explicit costs of attending college might be about tuition, books, room and board, and other expenses. 
But in addition, during the hours that you are attending class and studying, it is impossible to work at a 
paying job. Thus, graduate school imposes both an out-of-pocket cost and an opportunity cost of lost 
earnings.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ What if the price of a good changes?
â€¢ Suppose that, the price of bus ticket increased to 1,400 won.
â€¢ A price increase for bus tickets would have no effect on the ability to purchase Ramen. 
â€¢ But it would reduce the number of bus tickets which Pepe could afford to buy.
â€¢ What happens in the budget constraint? Redraw it.

2. Utility
â€¢ People desire goods and services for the satisfaction or utility from using those goods and services.
â€¢ Utility is the term which economists use to describe a personâ€™s level of satisfaction/usefulness or 
happiness with his or her choices.
â€¢ Of course, in our daily life, we donâ€™t measure such a thing. But, in model, it can be a quite useful 
instrument to replicate the underlying incentive structure of each individuals.
2. Utility
Economists assume the feature of utility
1.The more of some good one consumes, the more utility 
one obtains.
2. As a person consumes more of a good, the additional (or 
marginal) utility from each additional unit of the good 
declines.
2. Utility
â€¢ It is a general pattern that consumption of the first few units of good tends to bring a higher level of 
utility than consumption of later units.
â€¢ Suppose that you are in thirsty. You can compare the degree to which the first few drops of water relieve 
the thirst and the extent to which the drinking water later resolves the thirst.
â€¢ Economists refer to this pattern as the law of diminishing marginal utility.
â€¢ It means that, the utility of a person receives from consuming the first unit of a good is typically more 
than the utility received from consuming the fifth or the tenth unit of that same good.
2. Utility
â€¢ The law of diminishing marginal utility explains why people and societies rarely make all-or-nothing 
choices. 
â€¢ Most of people would not say, â€œMy favorite food is potato, so I will eat nothing but only potatoes from 
now on.â€
â€¢ Even if you get a very high level of utility from your favorite food, if you ate it exclusively, the marginal 
utility from those last few servings would not be very high. 
2. Utility

â€¢ Relationship between goods
â€¢ Substitute goods : an increase in the demand of A causes an decrease in the demand of B (-)
â€¢ Complementary goods : an increase in the demand of A causes an increase in the demand of B (+)
â€¢ Then, consider price effect on other good

â€¢ On complementary goods : an increase in the price of A causes an decrease in the demand of B (-)

Producerâ€™s optimization problem
â—¦ Business sector or firms combines inputs of labor, capital, land, and raw or 
finished component materials to produce outputs.
â—¦ This activity of production includes not only manufacturing but also any 
process or service that creates value, including transportation, distribution, 
wholesale and retail sales.

Producerâ€™s optimization problem
â—¦ Profit = Revenue â€“ cost

â—¦ Cost = the amount that the firm pays to make and sell their products is called total cost. 
â—¦ The cost structure of firms can be broken down into some 
common underlying patterns. In the short run, we can classify the 
costs into fixed costs and variable costs.
â—¦ Fixed costs are the costs that cannot be changed in the short run.
â—¦ Variable costs are the costs that can be changed.
The structure of production cost
â—¦ Fixed costs are expenditures that do not change regardless of the level of 
production, at least not in the short term.
â—¦ For example, the cost of building factory or buying heavy equipment, research and 
development costs, advertising expenses. 
â—¦ The level of fixed costs varies according to the feature of the products or 
industry. 
â—¦ For instance, manufacturing mobile phone or computer chips requires an 
expensive factory. But, a food-truck or a painting artist can get by with 
relatively less fixed costs.
The structure of production cost
â—¦ Variable costs are incurred in the act of producing.
â—¦ For example, wages and cost to buy intermediate goods are variable costs.
â—¦ The more you produce, the greater the variable cost.
â—¦ Total cost = fixed cost + variable cost.
The nature of production
â—¦ Two assumptions:
1. Positivity (with respect to input)
2. Law of diminishing marginal production
â—¦ Marginal product of any input : the additional quantity of output obtained 
from one additional unit of that input.

equipment, are 100.

â—¦ Variable cost :  price of input  x  quantity of input.
â—¦ When one unit of the input (worker) is added, the cost would be increased as much as the 
price of the input (50 for the wage).

Introduction 
of economics
: Market Equilibrium
HANDONG GLOBAL UNIVERSITY
0. Introduction
In this week, we will learn about:
- Demand, Supply, and Equilibrium in Markets for 
Goods and Services
-   Shifts in Demand and Supply curves
- Changes in Equilibrium Price and Quantity
- Price Ceilings and Price Floors
Market Equilibrium

1. Demand curve
Demand the amount of some good or service consumers are willing and able 
to purchase at each price. 
Demand for each good and services can be obtained by individual consumerâ€™s 
preference and their budgets.
Demand represent the amount of wiliness to pay of the society. 
1. Demand curve
The total number of units purchased at that price is called the quantity 
demanded. 
So, In economic terminology, demand is not the same as quantity demanded. 
Demand is mean the relationship between a range of prices and the quantities 
demanded at those prices.
1. Demand curve
P         Q
P         Q 
Economists call this inverse relationship between price and quantity 
demanded the law of demand. 
The law of demand assumes that all other variables that affect demand are 
held constant.
1. Demand curve
Q
P
1. Demand curve
Demand curves can somewhat different for each product. 
They may appear relatively steep or flat, or they may be straight or curved. 
Nearly all demand curves share the fundamental similarity that they slope 
down from left to right. 
2. Supply curve
Quantity supplied means the amount of some good or service a producer is 
willing to supply at each price. 
Price is what the producer receives for selling one unit of a good or service. 
A rise in price almost always leads to an increase in the quantity supplied of 
that good or service, while a fall in price will decrease the quantity supplied.
2. Supply curve
Q
P

3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess supply
What will be happened in next?
Some chicken houses can not sell their chickens. So, Raw chickens, oils, flours 
at their storages starts to go bad.
Some chicken houses will want to cut prices, because it is better to sell at a 
lower price than not to sell at all. 
So, if the price is above the equilibrium level, incentives built into the structure 
of demand and supply pressures for the price to fall toward the equilibrium.
3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess demand

3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess demand
Consumers always are waiting their order and chicken houses says that they 
are filled with orders and there are no more stock of raw meats.
Itâ€™s not difficult for chicken houses to realize that even if they raise the price, 
they can sell their stock out.
So, if the price is below the equilibrium level, incentives built into the structure 
of demand and supply pressures for the price to rise toward the equilibrium.

4. Equilibrium
The word â€œequilibriumâ€ means â€œbalance.â€ 
If a market is at its equilibrium price and quantity, then it has no reason to 
move away from that point. 
However, if a market is not at equilibrium, then economic pressures arise to 
move the market toward the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity.
4. Equilibrium
In 1890, the famous economist Alfred Marshall wrote that asking whether 
supply or demand determined a price was like arguing
â€œwhether it is the upper or the 
under blade of a pair of 
scissors that cuts a piece of 
paper.â€ 
5. Shift of demand curve
Price, however, is not the only thing that influences demand and supply.
What if overall consumerâ€™s income has changed? 
Sometime preferences can be suddenly changed.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
5. Shift of demand curve
Q
P
D0
1000
E
15000
800
18000
1200
D1
D2
5. Shift of demand curve
Does the higher income always bring greater demand?
A product whose demand rises when income rises is called a normal good.
but, there is a few exceptions to this pattern do exist. 
A product whose demand falls when income rises is called an inferior good. 
5. Shift of demand curve
And, for some goods such as luxury cars, fine cuisines, or jewelry, the effect of 
a rise in income can be especially pronounced.
We called those luxury goods.
A luxury good is a good for which demand increases more than proportionally 
as income rises, 
5. Shift of demand curve
Of course, income is not the only factor that causes a shift in demand.
We can think about some of other factors that shift demand curves.
One of those is changing tastes or preferences.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
It might cause a severe avoiding to eat chickens.
5. Shift of demand curve
Demographic changes can also be a important factor.
Actually, the demographic changes is combined with the changes in preference.
Since the consumption preference of youth and old person is quite different, 
changes in the demographic structure directly affects the overall preference of 
the society.
5. Shift of demand curve
Another example is the housing demand.
Since the demand for owning houses is usually peaked in the middle age about 
40s, the overall housing demand can also be peaked, when the number of 
middle-aged in the country is the highest level.
Some economists have tried to predict the future housing prices by using 
predictable demographic changes.
Mankiw, N. G., & Weil, D. N. (1989). The baby boom, the baby bust, and the 
housing market. Regional science and urban economics, 19(2), 235-258.
5. Shift of demand curve
It is also true that expectations about the future price (or expectations about 
tastes and preferences, income, and so on) can affect demand.
For example, if people hear that a hurricane is coming, they may rush to the 
store to buy flashlight batteries and bottled water. 
These changes can push the demand curve to the right.
5. Shift of demand curve
One interest thing is that some goods can be seriously affected by the 
expectation.
For example, we can think about housing market.
Demand for housing is not only determined  by preferences, but also by the 
expectations for capital gain.
This feature of housing markets sometimes causes speculations in housing 
markets.
6. Shift of supply curve
How about the supply curves? 
One of most important factor affecting the supply curve might be the 
production cost.
If a firm faces lower costs of production, a firmâ€™s profits go up. This can be 
shown by the supply curve shifting to the right.
if a firm faces higher costs of production, then it will earn lower profits at any 
given selling price for its products. In this case, the supply curve shifts to the 
left.
6. Shift of supply curve
Q
P
S0
1000
E
15000
800
18000
1200
S1 S2
6. Shift of supply curve
Several other things affect the cost of production, too. 
We can think about new technologies for production, and some government 
policies.
6. Shift of supply curve
When producers develops or discovers a technology that allows the firm to 
produce at a lower cost, the supply curve will shift to the right, as well. 
Think about the cost of raising a chicken in chicken farm and the poultry 
factory system.
6. Shift of supply curve
Government policies also can affect the cost of production and the supply 
curve through taxes, regulations, and subsidies.
A subsidy occurs when the government pays a firm directly or reduces the 
firmâ€™s taxes if the firm carries out certain actions. 
From the firmâ€™s perspective, taxes or regulations are an additional cost of 
production that shifts supply to the left, leading the firm to produce a lower 
quantity at every given price. 
So, government subsidies reduce the cost of production and increase supply at 
every given price, shifting supply to the right.
7. Price controls
In some cases, discontent over prices turns into public pressure on politicians
7. Price controls
Laws that government enacts to regulate prices are called Price controls.
Price controls come in two ways.
A price ceiling keeps a price from rising above a certain level.
And, a price floor keeps a price from falling below a certain level. 
7. Price controls

7. Price controls
A price floor is the lowest legal price that can be paid in the market.
Price floors are sometimes called price supports. 
Because they support a price by preventing it from falling below a certain level. 
7. Price controls
Q
P
1000
15000
Eâ€™

E
7. Price controls
The demand and supply model shows how people and firms will react to the 
incentives provided by these laws to control prices.
As a result, It will often lead to undesirable consequences. 
It implies alternative policy tools can often achieve the desired goals of price 
control laws, while avoiding at least some of their costs and tradeoffs.

1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ Suppose there is a consumer whose name is Pepe. He is the representative agent of all customers in our 
society.

1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ We want to capture that consumers have a limited amount of income to spend on the things they need and 
want.
â€¢ Pepe has 5,600 wons in spending money each week.
â€¢ He can allocate this spending between meal ticket and shirts. 
â€¢ The meal tickets cost 700 wons each, and the shirts are 1,400 wons each.

1. Budget Constraint

â€¢ Because, in a modern economy, people choose from thousands of goods.
â€¢ However, thinking about a model with many goods can be just a straightforward extension of what we 
discussed here.
â€¢ The point is that there is always a trade-off problem in decisions.

1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ Economists call it opportunity cost.
â€¢ Opportunity cost indicate what have to be given up to obtain something. In other words, opportunity cost 
is the value of the next best alternative.
â€¢ For Pepe, the opportunity cost of 1 shirt is the 2 meal tickets. 
â€¢ He would decide to buy one more shirt, If the value of the extra shirt exceed the value of the alternative 
(2 meal tickets).
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ A fundamental principle of economics is that every choice has an opportunity cost.
â€¢ If you sleep through your economics class, the opportunity cost might be the time which would be spent 
to make up the class.
â€¢ If you choose to marry one person, you give up the opportunity to marry anyone else. 
â€¢ In short, opportunity cost is all around us and part of human existence.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ In many cases, it is reasonable to refer to the opportunity cost as the price.
â€¢ For example, attending graduate school is the case where the opportunity cost exceeds the monetary cost. 
The explicit costs of attending college might be about tuition, books, room and board, and other expenses. 
But in addition, during the hours that you are attending class and studying, it is impossible to work at a 
paying job. Thus, graduate school imposes both an out-of-pocket cost and an opportunity cost of lost 
earnings.
1. Budget Constraint

â€¢ Suppose that, the price of bus ticket increased to 1,400 won.
â€¢ A price increase for bus tickets would have no effect on the ability to purchase Ramen. 
â€¢ But it would reduce the number of bus tickets which Pepe could afford to buy.

2. Utility
â€¢ People desire goods and services for the satisfaction or utility from using those goods and services.
â€¢ Utility is the term which economists use to describe a personâ€™s level of satisfaction/usefulness or 
happiness with his or her choices.
â€¢ Of course, in our daily life, we donâ€™t measure such a thing. But, in model, it can be a quite useful 
instrument to replicate the underlying incentive structure of each individuals.
2. Utility
Economists assume the feature of utility
1.The more of some good one consumes, the more utility 
one obtains.
2. As a person consumes more of a good, the additional (or 
marginal) utility from each additional unit of the good 
declines.
2. Utility
â€¢ It is a general pattern that consumption of the first few units of good tends to bring a higher level of 
utility than consumption of later units.
â€¢ Suppose that you are in thirsty. You can compare the degree to which the first few drops of water relieve 
the thirst and the extent to which the drinking water later resolves the thirst.
â€¢ Economists refer to this pattern as the law of diminishing marginal utility.
â€¢ It means that, the utility of a person receives from consuming the first unit of a good is typically more 
than the utility received from consuming the fifth or the tenth unit of that same good.
2. Utility
â€¢ The law of diminishing marginal utility explains why people and societies rarely make all-or-nothing 
choices. 
â€¢ Most of people would not say, â€œMy favorite food is potato, so I will eat nothing but only potatoes from 
now on.â€
â€¢ Even if you get a very high level of utility from your favorite food, if you ate it exclusively, the marginal 
utility from those last few servings would not be very high. 
2. Utility

â€¢ When a price changes,
â€¢ Substitution effect : change in relative price (the slope in budget constraint)
â€¢ Income effect (of a price change) : shift in real purchasing power

Price effect
â€¢ Price effect : an increase in price causes an decrease in demand (-)
* Special case : Giffen goods â€“ price effect (+)
â€¢ Relationship between goods
â€¢ Substitute goods : an increase in the demand of A causes an decrease in the demand of B (-)
â€¢ Complementary goods : an increase in the demand of A causes an increase in the demand of B (+)
â€¢ Then, consider price effect on other good
â€¢ On substitute goods : an increase in the price of A causes an increase in the demand of B (+)
â€¢ On complementary goods : an increase in the price of A causes an decrease in the demand of B (-)
Demand curve
â€¢ What is demand curve? The relationship between price and quantity demanded
â€¢ What is the quantity demanded? We know what occurs if consumers follow their self-interest. => The 
optimal decision of consumption

Producerâ€™s optimization problem
â—¦ Business sector or firms combines inputs of labor, capital, land, and raw or

â—¦ The cost structure of firms can be broken down into some 
common underlying patterns. In the short run, we can classify the 
costs into fixed costs and variable costs.
â—¦ Fixed costs are the costs that cannot be changed in the short run.
â—¦ Variable costs are the costs that can be changed.
The structure of production cost
â—¦ Fixed costs are expenditures that do not change regardless of the level of 
production, at least not in the short term.
â—¦ For example, the cost of building factory or buying heavy equipment, research and 
development costs, advertising expenses. 
â—¦ The level of fixed costs varies according to the feature of the products or 
industry. 
â—¦ For instance, manufacturing mobile phone or computer chips requires an 
expensive factory. But, a food-truck or a painting artist can get by with 
relatively less fixed costs.
The structure of production cost
â—¦ Variable costs are incurred in the act of producing.
â—¦ For example, wages and cost to buy intermediate goods are variable costs.
â—¦ The more you produce, the greater the variable cost.
â—¦ Total cost = fixed cost + variable cost.
The nature of production

1. Positivity (with respect to input)
2. Law of diminishing marginal production
â—¦ Marginal product of any input : the additional quantity of output obtained 
from one additional unit of that input.

â—¦ When one unit of the input (worker) is added, the cost would be increased as much as the 
price of the input (50 for the wage).

Introduction 
of economics
: Market Equilibrium
HANDONG GLOBAL UNIVERSITY
0. Introduction
In this week, we will learn about:
- Demand, Supply, and Equilibrium in Markets for 
Goods and Services
-   Shifts in Demand and Supply curves
- Changes in Equilibrium Price and Quantity
- Price Ceilings and Price Floors
Market Equilibrium

1. Demand curve
Demand the amount of some good or service consumers are willing and able 
to purchase at each price. 
Demand for each good and services can be obtained by individual consumerâ€™s 
preference and their budgets.
Demand represent the amount of wiliness to pay of the society. 
1. Demand curve
The total number of units purchased at that price is called the quantity 
demanded. 
So, In economic terminology, demand is not the same as quantity demanded. 
Demand is mean the relationship between a range of prices and the quantities 
demanded at those prices.
1. Demand curve
P         Q
P         Q 
Economists call this inverse relationship between price and quantity 
demanded the law of demand. 
The law of demand assumes that all other variables that affect demand are 
held constant.
1. Demand curve
Q
P
1. Demand curve
Demand curves can somewhat different for each product. 
They may appear relatively steep or flat, or they may be straight or curved. 
Nearly all demand curves share the fundamental similarity that they slope 
down from left to right. 
2. Supply curve
Quantity supplied means the amount of some good or service a producer is 
willing to supply at each price. 
Price is what the producer receives for selling one unit of a good or service. 
A rise in price almost always leads to an increase in the quantity supplied of 
that good or service, while a fall in price will decrease the quantity supplied.
2. Supply curve
Q
P
3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess supply

3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess supply
What will be happened in next?
Some chicken houses can not sell their chickens. So, Raw chickens, oils, flours 
at their storages starts to go bad.
Some chicken houses will want to cut prices, because it is better to sell at a 
lower price than not to sell at all. 
So, if the price is above the equilibrium level, incentives built into the structure 
of demand and supply pressures for the price to fall toward the equilibrium.
3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess demand

3. Disequilibrium â€“ excess demand
Consumers always are waiting their order and chicken houses says that they 
are filled with orders and there are no more stock of raw meats.
Itâ€™s not difficult for chicken houses to realize that even if they raise the price, 
they can sell their stock out.
So, if the price is below the equilibrium level, incentives built into the structure 
of demand and supply pressures for the price to rise toward the equilibrium.

4. Equilibrium
The word â€œequilibriumâ€ means â€œbalance.â€ 
If a market is at its equilibrium price and quantity, then it has no reason to 
move away from that point. 
However, if a market is not at equilibrium, then economic pressures arise to 
move the market toward the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity.
4. Equilibrium
In 1890, the famous economist Alfred Marshall wrote that asking whether 
supply or demand determined a price was like arguing
â€œwhether it is the upper or the 
under blade of a pair of 
scissors that cuts a piece of 
paper.â€ 

5. Shift of demand curve
Price, however, is not the only thing that influences demand and supply.
What if overall consumerâ€™s income has changed? 
Sometime preferences can be suddenly changed.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
5. Shift of demand curve
Q
P
D0
1000
E
15000
800
18000

D1

5. Shift of demand curve
Does the higher income always bring greater demand?
A product whose demand rises when income rises is called a normal good.
but, there is a few exceptions to this pattern do exist. 
A product whose demand falls when income rises is called an inferior good. 
5. Shift of demand curve
And, for some goods such as luxury cars, fine cuisines, or jewelry, the effect of 
a rise in income can be especially pronounced.
We called those luxury goods.
A luxury good is a good for which demand increases more than proportionally 
as income rises, 
5. Shift of demand curve
Of course, income is not the only factor that causes a shift in demand.
We can think about some of other factors that shift demand curves.
One of those is changing tastes or preferences.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
It might cause a severe avoiding to eat chickens.
5. Shift of demand curve
Demographic changes can also be a important factor.
Actually, the demographic changes is combined with the changes in preference.
Since the consumption preference of youth and old person is quite different, 
changes in the demographic structure directly affects the overall preference of 
the society.
5. Shift of demand curve
Another example is the housing demand.
Since the demand for owning houses is usually peaked in the middle age about 
40s, the overall housing demand can also be peaked, when the number of 
middle-aged in the country is the highest level.
Some economists have tried to predict the future housing prices by using 
predictable demographic changes.
Mankiw, N. G., & Weil, D. N. (1989). The baby boom, the baby bust, and the 
housing market. Regional science and urban economics, 19(2), 235-258.
5. Shift of demand curve
It is also true that expectations about the future price (or expectations about 
tastes and preferences, income, and so on) can affect demand.
For example, if people hear that a hurricane is coming, they may rush to the 
store to buy flashlight batteries and bottled water. 
These changes can push the demand curve to the right.
5. Shift of demand curve
One interest thing is that some goods can be seriously affected by the 
expectation.
For example, we can think about housing market.
Demand for housing is not only determined  by preferences, but also by the 
expectations for capital gain.
This feature of housing markets sometimes causes speculations in housing 
markets.
6. Shift of supply curve
How about the supply curves? 
One of most important factor affecting the supply curve might be the 
production cost.
If a firm faces lower costs of production, a firmâ€™s profits go up. This can be 
shown by the supply curve shifting to the right.
if a firm faces higher costs of production, then it will earn lower profits at any 
given selling price for its products. In this case, the supply curve shifts to the 
left.
6. Shift of supply curve
Q
P
S0
1000
E
15000
800
18000
1200
S1 S2
6. Shift of supply curve
Several other things affect the cost of production, too. 
We can think about new technologies for production, and some government 
policies.
6. Shift of supply curve
When producers develops or discovers a technology that allows the firm to 
produce at a lower cost, the supply curve will shift to the right, as well. 
Think about the cost of raising a chicken in chicken farm and the poultry 
factory system.

6. Shift of supply curve
Government policies also can affect the cost of production and the supply 
curve through taxes, regulations, and subsidies.
A subsidy occurs when the government pays a firm directly or reduces the 
firmâ€™s taxes if the firm carries out certain actions. 
From the firmâ€™s perspective, taxes or regulations are an additional cost of 
production that shifts supply to the left, leading the firm to produce a lower 
quantity at every given price. 
So, government subsidies reduce the cost of production and increase supply at 
every given price, shifting supply to the right.
7. Price controls
In some cases, discontent over prices turns into public pressure on politicians

7. Price controls
Laws that government enacts to regulate prices are called Price controls.
Price controls come in two ways.
A price ceiling keeps a price from rising above a certain level.
And, a price floor keeps a price from falling below a certain level.

7. Price controls
A price floor is the lowest legal price that can be paid in the market.
Price floors are sometimes called price supports. 
Because they support a price by preventing it from falling below a certain level. 
7. Price controls

7. Price controls
The demand and supply model shows how people and firms will react to the 
incentives provided by these laws to control prices.
As a result, It will often lead to undesirable consequences. 
It implies alternative policy tools can often achieve the desired goals of price 
control laws, while avoiding at least some of their costs and tradeoffs.

1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ Suppose there is a consumer whose name is Pepe. He is the representative agent of all customers in our 
society.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ We want to capture that consumers have a limited amount of income to spend on the things they need and 
want.
â€¢ Pepe has 5,600 wons in spending money each week.
â€¢ He can allocate this spending between meal ticket and shirts. 
â€¢ The meal tickets cost 700 wons each, and the shirts are 1,400 wons each.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ Of course, the budget constraint diagram containing just two goods is not realistic. 
â€¢ Because, in a modern economy, people choose from thousands of goods.
â€¢ However, thinking about a model with many goods can be just a straightforward extension of what we 
discussed here.
â€¢ The point is that there is always a trade-off problem in decisions.

1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ Economists call it opportunity cost.
â€¢ Opportunity cost indicate what have to be given up to obtain something. In other words, opportunity cost 
is the value of the next best alternative.
â€¢ For Pepe, the opportunity cost of 1 shirt is the 2 meal tickets. 
â€¢ He would decide to buy one more shirt, If the value of the extra shirt exceed the value of the alternative 
(2 meal tickets).
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ A fundamental principle of economics is that every choice has an opportunity cost.
â€¢ If you sleep through your economics class, the opportunity cost might be the time which would be spent 
to make up the class.
â€¢ If you choose to marry one person, you give up the opportunity to marry anyone else. 
â€¢ In short, opportunity cost is all around us and part of human existence.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ In many cases, it is reasonable to refer to the opportunity cost as the price.
â€¢ For example, attending graduate school is the case where the opportunity cost exceeds the monetary cost. 
The explicit costs of attending college might be about tuition, books, room and board, and other expenses. 
But in addition, during the hours that you are attending class and studying, it is impossible to work at a 
paying job. Thus, graduate school imposes both an out-of-pocket cost and an opportunity cost of lost 
earnings.
1. Budget Constraint
â€¢ What if the price of a good changes?
â€¢ Suppose that, the price of bus ticket increased to 1,400 won.
â€¢ A price increase for bus tickets would have no effect on the ability to purchase Ramen. 
â€¢ But it would reduce the number of bus tickets which Pepe could afford to buy.
â€¢ What happens in the budget constraint? Redraw it.
